questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following genes is associated with Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
The gene associated with Crohn's disease is the NOD2 gene. Št is present on chromosome 16. Nucleotide-binding oligomeri˜ation domain 2 (NOD2) acts as a cytoplasmic sensor of microbial 
products. Defective NOD2 gene results in defective innate immunity. When the innate immunity 
is unable to clear the bacteria, there is an exaggerated response of the immune system (T-cells) 
resulting in damage to the host tissue. Option B: JAK2 mutation is associated with polycythemia vera. Option C: BRAF V600E mutation is associated with melanoma, papillary thyroid cancer, and 
serous ovarian cancers. Option D: STAT‚ mutations are associated with the autosomal dominant hyper-ŠgE syndrome.

Question 3: Šn patients who have undergone an appendectomy, there is a lower risk for developing which 
of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
Appendectomy is protective against ulcerative colitis. Smoking is also seen to have a protective effect on ulcerative colitis but it is a risk factor for 
developing Crohn's disease.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following infections should you rule out before diagnosing a patient with ŠBD on 
the basis of clinical symptoms and biopsy findings?
questions.explanation:
Campylobacter enteritis should be ruled out before diagnosing a patient with ŠBD. Campylobacter enteritis can mimic the clinical presentation and biopsy appearance of ulcerative 
colitis or Crohn’s disease (ŠBD). Hence, it should be ruled out, especially in persons with a history 
of: • Foreign travel • Significant animal contact • Šmmunodeficiency • Exposure incurring a high risk of transmission. Št can also cause a relapse of established ulcerative colitis. A definitive diagnosis of campylobacter infection can be made by culture or real-time ‰CR.

Question 8: Which of the following sites is most commonly involved in Crohn’s disease? 384 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:

Sold by @itachibot The most commonly affected site in Crohn's disease is the terminal ileum. Other commonly affected sites in Crohn's disease include the small intestine and the 
colon. Although it can affect any part of the GŠ tract from mouth to anus, the rectum is usually 
spared. On the other hand, the rectum is almost always involved in ulcerative colitis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presented with acute severe small bowel obstruction to the ER. An emergency small 
bowel resection was done. The resected specimen is shown below. What could be the likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above specimen of the small bowel shows creeping fat which is a feature of Crohn's 
disease (CD). Mesenteric fat is normally seen along the longitudinal axis of the intestine. However, in Crohn's 
disease, excessive fibrofatty proliferation results in mesenteric fat wrapping around the inflamed 
bowel. This is called creeping fat. Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's 
disease. Strictures can cause bowel obstruction. Other gross features seen in Crohn's disease are: • Transmural inflammation- full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel • Aphthous ulcers- small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema • Longitudinal ulcers- linear or serpiginous deep ulcers • Skip lesions- involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening normal 
mucosa • Cobblestone appearance- deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal 
mucosa The image below shows cobblestone appearance in Crohn's disease. 392 
Sold by @itachibot

Question 10: A 28-year-old man presented with diarrhea, bloody stools, weight loss, and intermittent fever 
for the past 2 months. Endoscopy revealed the following. What is the most probable 
diagnosis? 385 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The clinical presentation along with the endoscopy image showing a cobblestone appearance are 
suggestive of Crohn's disease (CD). Endoscopic findings in Crohn's disease include: • Aphthous ulcers - small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema • Longitudinal ulcers - linear or serpiginous deep ulcers • Cobblestone appearance - deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal 
mucosa • Strictures • Fistulas Strictures and fistulae are the commonly associated complications of long-standing Crohn's 
disease.

questions.question:
Question 11: A •0-year-old chronic smoker is being evaluated for chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, and weight 
loss. On examination, pallor was noted. ‰eripheral smear revealed macrocytes and 
hypersegmented neutrophils. Stool examination showed elevated calprotectin and a positive 
guaiac test. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The above scenario is suggestive of Crohn's disease presenting as jejunoileitis. This is evidenced 
by the presence of features of malabsorption such as steatorrhea, chronic diarrhea, and vitamin 
B12 deficiency anemia. The fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin are elevated in inflammatory conditions like inflammatory 
bowel disease, but not in irritable bowel syndrome. The stool guaiac test or guaiac fecal occult blood test (gFOBT) reveals the presence of microscopic 
levels of blood suggesting Crohn's disease. Gross bleeding per rectum is more characteristic of 
ulcerative colitis. Additionally, smoking is a risk factor for Crohn's disease. However, it is a protective 
factor in ulcerative colitis.

questions.question: Question 15: What is the earliest radiographic feature of Crohn's disease?
questions.explanation:
Aphthous ulcers seen in Crohn's disease are the earliest radiological signs on small bowel 
follow-through study. They are shallow ulcers that are often multiple and separated by normal intervening mucosa. They 
are also the earliest macroscopic findings of Crohn's disease. Features on barium small bowel follow-through in Crohn's disease include: • Mucosal ulcers: • Aphthous ulcers initially • Deep ulcers (more than ‚ mm depth) • Longitudinal fissures • Transverse stripes • Severe mucosal ulcers lead to cobblestone appearance • Sinus tracts and fistulae • Creeping fat: widely separated loops of the bowel due to fibrofatty proliferation • Thickened folds due to edema • ‰seudo-diverticula formation: due to contraction at the site of ulcer with ballooning of the 
opposite site • String sign of Kantor: tubular narrowing due to spasm or stricture depending on the chronicity • Rose thorn appearance • ‰artial obstruction. CT and MR enterography have a higher sensitivity for the diagnosis of Crohn’s disease. They may 
reveal additional features such as: • Fat halo sign - submucosal fat deposition • Comb sign - engorgement of the vasa recta. Šn gastric Crohn's disease, conical narrowing of the antrum may be seen. This is called Ram’s horn 
sign. The image below shows aphthous ulcers (focal contrast with surrounding haloes of mucosal 
edema) 395

Question 16: 387 
Sold by @itachibot Which among the following is the earliest radiologic change seen on barium enema in 
ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation:
The earliest radiological change of ulcerative colitis seen on barium enema is fine mucosal 
granularity. Double-contrast barium enema allows for exquisite detail of the colonic mucosa and also allows 
the bowel proximal to strictures to be assessed. Št is however contraindicated if acute severe colitis 
is present due to the risk of perforation. Early changes in ulcerative colitis: • Mucosal granularity • Fine granular pattern 397 
Sold by @itachibot • Mucosal stippling • Collar button ulcers • Deep collar stud ulcers. The below contrast radiograph shows granular mucosa typical of ulcerative colitis. Option A: Collar button ulcers are small deep ulcers in which the button surface corresponds to 
the eroded ulcer base and the button neck corresponds to the undermined and preserved mucosa. 
They are also seen in ulcerative colitis. Option C: String sign represents circumferential inflammation and fibrosis, resulting in long 
segments of luminal narrowing as shown below. Št is more characteristic of Crohn's disease. Option D: Ram's horn sign is seen in gastric Crohn's disease. 398 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following findings is seen in patients with ulcerative colitis?
questions.explanation:
‰seudopolyps are seen in ulcerative colitis. They are formed due to alternating inflammation and 
regeneration of the ulcerated mucosal epithelium in ulcerative colitis. Other gross findings in ulcerative colitis include: • Continuous mucosal inflammation of the colon most commonly involving the rectum • Fine mucosal granularity • Collar button ulcers • ‰seudopolyps. Rose thorn appearance, skip lesions, and pseudodiverticula are features of Crohn's disease.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following complications is unlikely to occur in a patient with ulcerative colitis?

options.a: Can occur years before the onset of bowel symptoms

questions.explanation:
Fistula is not a complication of ulcerative colitis. Št is seen in Crohn’s disease. Hemorrhage, malignant change, and toxic megacolon are complications of ulcerative colitis. Note: Stricture formation may be a complication of ulcerative colitis, but it is seen only in š-10% 
of patients. They are more commonly seen in Crohn's disease. 400
